root: ^Managing expectations is important, both those you set for yourself and those others set for you. How do you feel about the expectations people have for you?

s: ^I think they expect too much from me.
^I think they’re reasonable, but it’s hard to keep up.
^I don’t think people expect much from me at all.

Too_Much_Expectation: ^Teacher: It can be overwhelming when people expect a lot from you. Have you talked to anyone about how you’re feeling?

s: ^I tried, but they told me I needed to work harder.

Dont_Think_Understand: ^Teacher: Sometimes we think people won’t understand, but they might surprise you. It’s worth trying to communicate how you’re feeling.
Told_To_Work_Harder: ^Teacher: That can be tough to hear, especially when you’re already trying your best. Remember, you can only do what you’re capable of—don’t push yourself beyond your limits.
Reasonable_But_Hard: ^Teacher: It’s good that you see the expectations as reasonable, even if they’re challenging. What helps you stay motivated to meet them?

s: ^I try to focus on one thing at a time.

Focus_On_One_Thing: ^Teacher: Breaking things down into smaller tasks can make them more manageable. That’s a great strategy—keep it up.
Remind_Importance: ^Teacher: Reminding yourself why something matters is a powerful motivator. Keeping the bigger picture in mind will help you get through the tough times.
Low_Expectations: ^Teacher: When people don’t expect much, it can feel disheartening. But remember, you set your own expectations. What do you expect from yourself?

s: ^I expect to do better than people think I can.
^I’m not sure. I don’t really have expectations for myself.

Expect_To_Do_Better: ^Teacher: That’s the spirit. Defy the expectations others set for you. Show them—and yourself—what you’re capable of.
No_Self_Expectations: ^Teacher: It’s important to set expectations for yourself, even if they’re small. Start by setting one simple goal and working towards it.
